title: Nanoscale Decomposition Pathways of Low-Dimensional Quantum Materials
content: Quantum functional devices have surged to the forefront of research initiatives, increasing the need to comprehensively understand the performance and stability of low-dimensional quantum materials. In situ scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) represents an ideal platform for probing these materials at the nanoscale, largely because a wide array of structural dynamics can be examined with respect to time and temperature [1]. Here we specifically utilize a combination of two STEM instruments with distinct capabilities: (1) a low kV in situ STEM with secondary electron (SE), bright field, and high angle annular dark field (HAADF) detectors to understand the morphological transformations for panoptic insights, and (2) an aberration-corrected STEM with electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) to conduct detailed examinations of atomic structure and chemical transformations. By combining the resulting data, we can identify key moments involved in the decomposition of these materials and develop detailed mechanistic understanding.
